title: Critics: Ebola appointment latest in missteps by officials
content:
WASHINGTON — President Obama 's decision to name a skilled political operative as his Ebola czar rather than a medical expert is enraging critics as the latest in a series of missteps in the government 's response to the virus .
The White House touted Ron Klain 's `` extensive managerial experience '' as a key credential for the post . Klain 's résumé includes serving as chief of staff to Vice Presidents Gore and Biden . The White House noted Klain also took the lead role in implementing the Recovery Act , the massive government spending effort to revive the economy amid the recession .
That did n't assuage Sen. John McCain , who blasted Klain , 53 , as a `` Democratic apparatchik '' with no qualifications to deal with a public health crisis .
`` He has no experience or knowledge or background in medicine , '' McCain , the Arizona Republican who lost the 2008 presidential race to Obama , told Fox News .
However , the czar 's medical expertise is less important than the ability to coordinate agencies as diverse as the Pentagon and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention , said Julie Fischer , an associate professor at the Milken Institute School of Public Health at George Washington University and an expert on infectious diseases .
Klain 's appointment will allow experts , such as CDC Director Tom Frieden , to do what they do best — fighting disease , Fischer said Saturday .
A sign that Klain is succeeding will be a `` single voice at the top '' talking about the government 's response and clear lines of responsibility , Fischer said .
`` We 'll know it 's working when we see stronger coordinated messages across government in the next few days , '' Fischer said .
Meanwhile , Klain 's appointment follows a series of what critics have called missteps by federal and local officials in dealing with Ebola . Among them :
• The Centers for Disease Control allowed one of two nurses infected with the disease to travel by airplane after she reported an elevated temperature — a red flag given she treated Thomas Eric Duncan , the first Ebola case identified in the United States who died Oct. 8 . Frieden said the nurse , Amber Vinson , should not have been allowed to travel .
The CDC has reached out to fellow passengers on her Frontier Airline flight , although Vinson 's temperature was low enough she was unlikely to have passed on the virus , he said .
• A national nurses union maintains the infection of Vinson and her colleague , Nina Pham , at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas , resulted from improper equipment , procedures and training to deal with Duncan , the Ebola patient . Among the issues cited by National Nurses United were suits issued to nurses that left their necks exposed .
The CDC now has recommendations for medical personnel dealing with Ebola patients that includes complete coverage of skin and safe procedures for wearing and disposal of protective gear . The CDC also developed teams to deploy quickly to hospitals with suspected cases of Ebola to ensure they are handled safely .
• Monitoring travelers — or banning them — from affected countries in West Africa has become a political issue with the midterm elections just weeks away . There have been nearly 5,000 deaths among the 9,000 cases of Ebola in Guinea , Liberia and Sierra Leone , according to the World Health Organization . Rep. Tim Murphy , the Tennessee Republican who chaired a hearing on the government 's response to Ebola on Thursday , said banning travelers from the region could prevent spread of the disease .
`` The trust and credibility of the administration and government are waning , '' Murphy said . President Obama , in his weekly radio address on Saturday , said a ban could worsen the crisis by preventing medical personnel from traveling to the affected countries .
Obama sought to quell fears about the disease during his weekly radio address Saturday by noting just three of more than 300 million Americans had been infected of Ebola in the United States . It 's not easy to catch , Obama said , as it requires contact with bodily fluids from an infected patient , and it can be contained .
`` This is a serious disease , but we ca n't give in to hysteria or fear — because that only makes it harder to get people the accurate information they need , '' Obama said .
Klain is a good choice for Ebola czar , Sen. Bob Casey , D-Pa. , said in a statement on Saturday .
`` Ron Klain brings the management experience necessary to help ensure all relevant agencies are coordinating with one another and that the U.S. government and public health system is leveraging all the resources possible to protect the health and safety of the American public and fighting Ebola at its source in West Africa , '' Casey said .
content_original:
Tom Vanden Brook

USA TODAY

WASHINGTON — President Obama's decision to name a skilled political operative as his Ebola czar rather than a medical expert is enraging critics as the latest in a series of missteps in the government's response to the virus.

The White House touted Ron Klain's "extensive managerial experience" as a key credential for the post. Klain's résumé includes serving as chief of staff to Vice Presidents Gore and Biden. The White House noted Klain also took the lead role in implementing the Recovery Act, the massive government spending effort to revive the economy amid the recession.

That didn't assuage Sen. John McCain, who blasted Klain, 53, as a "Democratic apparatchik" with no qualifications to deal with a public health crisis.

"He has no experience or knowledge or background in medicine," McCain, the Arizona Republican who lost the 2008 presidential race to Obama, told Fox News.

However, the czar's medical expertise is less important than the ability to coordinate agencies as diverse as the Pentagon and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said Julie Fischer, an associate professor at the Milken Institute School of Public Health at George Washington University and an expert on infectious diseases.

Klain's appointment will allow experts, such as CDC Director Tom Frieden, to do what they do best — fighting disease, Fischer said Saturday.

A sign that Klain is succeeding will be a "single voice at the top" talking about the government's response and clear lines of responsibility, Fischer said.

"We'll know it's working when we see stronger coordinated messages across government in the next few days," Fischer said.

Meanwhile, Klain's appointment follows a series of what critics have called missteps by federal and local officials in dealing with Ebola. Among them:

• The Centers for Disease Control allowed one of two nurses infected with the disease to travel by airplane after she reported an elevated temperature — a red flag given she treated Thomas Eric Duncan, the first Ebola case identified in the United States who died Oct. 8. Frieden said the nurse, Amber Vinson, should not have been allowed to travel.

The CDC has reached out to fellow passengers on her Frontier Airline flight, although Vinson's temperature was low enough she was unlikely to have passed on the virus, he said.

• A national nurses union maintains the infection of Vinson and her colleague, Nina Pham, at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas, resulted from improper equipment, procedures and training to deal with Duncan, the Ebola patient. Among the issues cited by National Nurses United were suits issued to nurses that left their necks exposed.

The CDC now has recommendations for medical personnel dealing with Ebola patients that includes complete coverage of skin and safe procedures for wearing and disposal of protective gear. The CDC also developed teams to deploy quickly to hospitals with suspected cases of Ebola to ensure they are handled safely.

• Monitoring travelers — or banning them — from affected countries in West Africa has become a political issue with the midterm elections just weeks away. There have been nearly 5,000 deaths among the 9,000 cases of Ebola in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, according to the World Health Organization. Rep. Tim Murphy, the Tennessee Republican who chaired a hearing on the government's response to Ebola on Thursday, said banning travelers from the region could prevent spread of the disease.

"The trust and credibility of the administration and government are waning," Murphy said. President Obama, in his weekly radio address on Saturday, said a ban could worsen the crisis by preventing medical personnel from traveling to the affected countries.

Obama sought to quell fears about the disease during his weekly radio address Saturday by noting just three of more than 300 million Americans had been infected of Ebola in the United States. It's not easy to catch, Obama said, as it requires contact with bodily fluids from an infected patient, and it can be contained.

"This is a serious disease, but we can't give in to hysteria or fear — because that only makes it harder to get people the accurate information they need," Obama said.

Klain is a good choice for Ebola czar, Sen. Bob Casey, D-Pa., said in a statement on Saturday.

"Ron Klain brings the management experience necessary to help ensure all relevant agencies are coordinating with one another and that the U.S. government and public health system is leveraging all the resources possible to protect the health and safety of the American public and fighting Ebola at its source in West Africa," Casey said.
